Subelement.title: FCC Rules, descriptions, and definitions for the Amateur Radio Service, operator and station license responsibilities

Group.title: Amateur Radio Service: purpose and permissible use of the Amateur Radio Service, operator/primary station license grant; Meanings of basic terms used in FCC rules; Interference; RACES rules; Phonetics; Frequency Coordinator

Question.text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service as stated in the FCC rules and regulations?

Answer.text: Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?

Answer.text: Homeland Security
The FCC
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What are the FCC rules regarding the use of a phonetic alphabet for station identification in the Amateur Radio Service?

Answer.text: It is required when transmitting emergency messages
It is prohibited
It is required when in contact with foreign stations
It is encouraged

Question.text: How many operator/primary station license grants may be held by any one person?

Answer.text: No more than two
One for each band on which the person plans to operate
One for each permanent station location from which the person plans to operate

Question.text: What is proof of possession of an FCC-issued operator/primary license grant?

Answer.text: A printed operator/primary station license issued by the FCC must be displayed at the transmitter site
The control operator must have an operator/primary station license in his or her possession when in control of a transmitter
The control operator's operator/primary station license must appear in the FCC ULS consolidated licensee database
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a "beacon"?

Answer.text: A government transmitter marking the amateur radio band edges
A bulletin sent by the FCC to announce a national emergency
An amateur station transmitting communications for the purposes of observing propagation or related experimental activities
A continuous transmission of weather information authorized in the amateur bands by the National Weather Service

Question.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a "space station"?

Answer.text: Any satellite orbiting the earth
A manned satellite orbiting the earth
An amateur station located more than 50 km above the Earth's surface
An amateur station using amateur radio satellites for relay of signals

Question.text: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?

Answer.text: Frequency Spectrum Manager appointed by the FCC
Volunteer Frequency Coordinator recognized by local amateurs
FCC Regional Field Office
International Telecommunications Union

Question.text: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?

Answer.text: The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be repeater or auxiliary stations
FCC Regional Field Office

Question.text: Which of the following describes the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?

Answer.text: A radio service using amateur frequencies for emergency management or civil defense communications
A radio service using amateur stations for emergency management or civil defense communications
An emergency service using amateur operators certified by a civil defense organization as being enrolled in that organization
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?

Answer.text: To stop another amateur station which is breaking the FCC rules
At no time
When making short test transmissions
At any time, stations in the Amateur Radio Service are not protected from willful interference

Group.title: Authorized frequencies: frequency allocations; ITU; emission modes; restricted sub-bands; spectrum sharing; transmissions near band edges; contacting the International Space Station; power output

Question.text: What is the International Telecommunications Union (ITU)?

Answer.text: An agency of the United States Department of Telecommunications Management
A United Nations agency for information and communication technology issues
An independent frequency coordination agency
A department of the FCC

Question.text: Which amateur radio stations may make contact with an amateur radio station on the International Space Station (ISS) using 2 meter and 70 cm band frequencies?

Answer.text: Only members of amateur radio clubs at NASA facilities
Any amateur holding a Technician or higher-class license
Only the astronaut's family members who are hams
Contacts with the ISS are not permitted on amateur radio frequencies

Question.text: Which frequency is within the 6 meter amateur band?
Which amateur band are you using when your station is transmitting on 146.52 MHz?

Answer.text: 2 meter band
20 meter band
14 meter band
6 meter band

Question.text: What is the limitation for emissions on the frequencies between 219 and 220 MHz?

Answer.text: Spread spectrum only
Fixed digital message forwarding systems only
Emergency traffic only
Fast-scan television only

Question.text: On which HF bands does a Technician class operator have phone privileges?

Answer.text: 10 meters only
80 meters, 40 meters, 15 meters and 10 meters
30 meters only

Question.text: Which of the following VHF/UHF frequencies ranges are limited to CW only?

Answer.text: 50.0 MHz to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 MHz to 144.1 MHz
219 MHz to 220 MHz and 420.0 MHz to 420.1 MHz
902.0 MHz to 902.1 MHZ
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a result of the fact that the Amateur Radio Service is secondary in all or portions of some amateur bands (such as portions of the 70 cm band)?

Answer.text: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in those portions, and must avoid interfering with them
U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those portions
International communications are not permitted in those portions
Digital transmissions are not permitted in those portions

Question.text: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?

Answer.text: To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
To allow for transmitter frequency drift
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following HF bands have frequencies available to the Technician class operator for RTTY and data transmissions?

Answer.text: 10 meters, 12 meters, 17 meters, and 40 meters
10 meters, 15 meters, 40 meters, 80 meters
30 meters only
10 meters only

Question.text: What is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using their assigned portions of the HF bands?

Answer.text: 200 watts
100 watts
50 watts
10 watts

Question.text: Except for some specific restrictions, what is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using frequencies above 30 MHz?

Answer.text: 50 watts
100 watts
500 watt
1500 watts

Group.title: Operator licensing: operator classes; sequential and vanity call sign systems; international communications; reciprocal operation; places where the Amateur Radio Service is regulated by the FCC; name and address on FCC license database; license term; renewal; grace period

Question.text: For which license classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?

Answer.text: Novice, Technician, General, Advanced
Technician, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
Novice, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
Technician, General, Amateur Extra

Question.text: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?

Answer.text: Only a licensed amateur with a General or Amateur Extra class license
Only a licensed amateur with an Amateur Extra class license
Only a licensed amateur who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years
Any licensed amateur

Question.text: What types of international communications is an FCC-licensed amateur radio station permitted to make?

Answer.text: Communications incidental to the purposes of the Amateur Radio Service and remarks of a personal character
Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
Only communications incidental to contest exchanges, all other communications are prohibited
Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station

Question.text: When are you allowed to operate your amateur station in a foreign country?

Answer.text: When the foreign country authorizes it
When there is a mutual agreement allowing third party communications
When authorization permits amateur communications in a foreign language
When you are communicating with non-licensed individuals in another country

Question.text: Which of the following is a valid call sign for a Technician class amateur radio station?

Answer.text: All of these choices are correct

Question.text: From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit?

Answer.text: From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunications Union
From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
From anywhere within International Telecommunications Union (ITU) Regions 2 and 3
From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

Question.text: What may result when correspondence from the FCC is returned as undeliverable because the grantee failed to provide and maintain a correct mailing address with the FCC?

Answer.text: Fine or imprisonment
Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license
Require the licensee to be re-examined
A reduction of one rank in operator class

Question.text: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued primary station/operator amateur radio license grant?

Answer.text: Five years
Ten years
Twenty years

Question.text: What is the grace period following the expiration of an amateur license within which the license may be renewed?

Answer.text: Two years
Three years
Five years
Ten years

Question.text: How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you operate a transmitter on an Amateur Radio Service frequency?

Answer.text: 30 days after the test date
As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database
You must wait until you receive your license in the mail from the FCC

Question.text: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to operate a transmitter on Amateur Radio Service frequencies?

Answer.text: No, transmitting is not allowed until the FCC license database shows that the license has been renewed
Yes, but only if you identify using the suffix GP
Yes, but only during authorized nets
Yes, for up to two years

Group.title: Authorized and prohibited transmission: communications with other countries; music; exchange of information with other services; indecent language; compensation for use of station; retransmission of other amateur signals; codes and ciphers; sale of equipment; unidentified transmissions; one-way transmission

Question.text: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur radio stations prohibited from exchanging communications?

Answer.text: Any country whose administration has notified the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) that it objects to such communications
Any country whose administration has notified the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) that it objects to such communications
Any country engaged in hostilities with another country
Any country in violation of the War Powers Act of 1934

Question.text: Under which of the following circumstances may an amateur radio station make one-way transmissions?

Answer.text: Under no circumstances
When transmitting code practice, information bulletins, or transmissions necessary to provide emergency communications
At any time, as long as no music is transmitted
At any time, as long as the material being transmitted did not originate from a commercial broadcast station

Question.text: When is it permissible to transmit messages encoded to hide their meaning?

Answer.text: Only during contests
Only when operating mobile
Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft
Only when frequencies above 1280 MHz are used

Question.text: Under what conditions is an amateur station authorized to transmit music using a phone emission?

Answer.text: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications
When the music produces no spurious emissions
When the purpose is to interfere with an illegal transmission
When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz

Question.text: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?

Answer.text: When the equipment is normally used in an amateur station and such activity is not conducted on a regular basis
When the asking price is $100.00 or less
When the asking price is less than its appraised value
When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee or the control operator or their close relatives

Question.text: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?

Answer.text: The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
Any such language is prohibited
The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
There is no such prohibition

Question.text: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?

Answer.text: Auxiliary, beacon, or Earth stations
Repeater, auxiliary, or space stations
Beacon, repeater, or space stations
Earth, repeater, or space stations

Question.text: In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating that station?

Answer.text: When the communication is related to the sale of amateur equipment by the control operator's employer
When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution
When the communication is made to obtain emergency information for a local broadcast station
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Under which of the following circumstances are amateur stations authorized to transmit signals related to broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?

Answer.text: Only where such communications directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property
Only when broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
Only where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network
Only when using amateur repeaters linked to the internet

Question.text: What is the meaning of the term “broadcasting” in the FCC rules for the Amateur Radio Service?

Answer.text: Two-way transmissions by amateur stations
Transmission of music
Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

Question.text: When may an amateur station transmit without on-the-air identification?

Answer.text: When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
When the transmissions are unmodulated
When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
When transmitting signals to control model craft

Group.title: Control operator and control types: control operator required; eligibility; designation of control operator; privileges and duties; control point; local, automatic and remote control; location of control operator

Question.text: When is an amateur station permitted to transmit without a control operator?

Answer.text: When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station

Question.text: Who may be the control operator of a station communicating through an amateur satellite or space station?

Answer.text: Only an Amateur Extra class operator
A General class or higher licensee who has a satellite operator certification
Only an Amateur Extra class operator who is also an AMSAT member
Any amateur whose license privileges allow them to transmit on the satellite uplink frequency

Question.text: Who must designate the station control operator?

Answer.text: The station licensee
The FCC
The frequency coordinator
The ITU

Question.text: What determines the transmitting privileges of an amateur station?

Answer.text: The frequency authorized by the frequency coordinator
The frequencies printed on the license grant
The highest class of operator license held by anyone on the premises
The class of operator license held by the control operator

Question.text: What is an amateur station control point?

Answer.text: The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
The location of the station transmitting apparatus
The location at which the control operator function is performed
The mailing address of the station licensee

Question.text: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an exclusive Amateur Extra class operator segment of the amateur bands?

Answer.text: At no time
When operating a special event station
As part of a multi-operator contest team
When using a club station whose trustee is an Amateur Extra class operator licensee

Question.text: When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?

Answer.text: All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
Only the station licensee
Only the control operator
The control operator and the station licensee are equally responsible

Question.text: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?

Answer.text: Repeater operation
Controlling the station over the internet
Using a computer or other device to send CW automatically
Using a computer or other device to identify automatically

Question.text: Which of the following is true of remote control operation?

Answer.text: The control operator must be at the control point
A control operator is required at all times
The control operator indirectly manipulates the controls
All these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?

Answer.text: Repeater operation
Operating the station over the internet
Controlling a model aircraft, boat, or car by amateur radio
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?

Answer.text: The station custodian
The third-party participant
The person operating the station equipment
The station licensee

Group.title: Station identification; repeaters; third-party communications; club stations; FCC inspection

Question.text: When must the station licensee make the station and its records available for FCC inspection?

Answer.text: At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
At any time upon request by an FCC representative
Only after failing to comply with an FCC notice of violation
Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent

Question.text: When using tactical identifiers such as “Race Headquarters” during a community service net operation, how often must your station transmit the station’s FCC-assigned call sign?

Answer.text: Never, the tactical call is sufficient
Once during every hour
At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication
At the end of every transmission

Question.text: When is an amateur station required to transmit its assigned call sign?

Answer.text: At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
At least once during each transmission
At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

Question.text: Which of the following is an acceptable language to use for station identification when operating in a phone sub-band?

Answer.text: Any language recognized by the United Nations
Any language recognized by the ITU
The English language
English, French, or Spanish

Question.text: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?

Answer.text: Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
Send the call sign using a CW or phone emission
Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
Send the call sign using only a phone emission

Question.text: Which of the following formats of a self-assigned indicator is acceptable when identifying using a phone transmission?

Answer.text: KL7CC stroke W3
KL7CC slant W3
KL7CC slash W3
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a Technician class control operator?

Answer.text: The person must be a U.S. citizen
The foreign station must be one with which the U.S. has a third-party agreement
The licensed control operator must do the station identification
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is meant by the term "Third Party Communications"?

Answer.text: A message from a control operator to another amateur station control operator on behalf of another person
Amateur radio communications where three stations are in communications with one another
Operation when the transmitting equipment is licensed to a person other than the control operator
Temporary authorization for an unlicensed person to transmit on the amateur bands for technical experiments

Question.text: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?

Answer.text: Beacon station
Earth station
Repeater station
Message forwarding station

Question.text: Who is accountable should a repeater inadvertently retransmit communications that violate the FCC rules?

Answer.text: The control operator of the originating station
The control operator of the repeater
The owner of the repeater
Both the originating station and the repeater owner

Question.text: Which of the following is a requirement for the issuance of a club station license grant?

Answer.text: The trustee must have an Amateur Extra class operator license grant
The club must have at least four members
The club must be registered with the American Radio Relay League
All of these choices are correct

Group.title: Station operation: choosing an operating frequency; calling another station; test transmissions; procedural signs; use of minimum power; choosing an operating frequency; band plans; calling frequencies; repeater offsets

Question.text: Which of the following is a common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?

Answer.text: Plus or minus 5 Mhz
Plus or minus 600 kHz
Plus or minus 500 kHz
Plus or minus 1 Mhz

Question.text: What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 2 meter band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?

Answer.text: Plus or minus 5 Mhz
Plus or minus 600 kHz
Plus or minus 500 kHz
Plus or minus 1 Mhz

Question.text: What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?

Answer.text: Say "break, break," then say the station's call sign
Say the station's call sign, then identify with your call sign
Say "CQ" three times, then the other station's call sign
Wait for the station to call CQ, then answer it

Question.text: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?

Answer.text: Transmit "CQ" followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign
Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign

Question.text: Which of the following is required when making on-the-air test transmissions?

Answer.text: Identify the transmitting station
Conduct tests only between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. local time
Notify the FCC of the transmissions
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is meant by "repeater offset?"

Answer.text: The difference between a repeater’s transmit frequency and its receive frequency
The repeater has a time delay to prevent interference
The repeater station identification is done on a separate frequency
The number of simultaneous transmit frequencies used by a repeater

Question.text: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?

Answer.text: Call on the quarter hour
A new antenna is being tested (no station should answer)
Only the called station should transmit
Calling any station

Question.text: What brief statement indicates that you are listening on a repeater and looking for a contact?

Answer.text: The words “Hello test” followed by your call sign
Your call sign
The repeater call sign followed by your call sign
The letters “QSY” followed by your call sign

Question.text: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?

Answer.text: A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band
A mandated list of operating schedules
A list of scheduled net frequencies
A plan devised by a club to indicate frequency band usage

Question.text: What kind of communication is taking place when an amateur station is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?

Answer.text: Full duplex

Question.text: Which of the following is a guideline when choosing an operating frequency for calling CQ?

Answer.text: Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
Ask if the frequency is in use
Make sure you are in your assigned band
All of these choices are correct

Group.title: VHF/UHF operating practices: SSB phone; FM repeater; simplex; splits and shifts; CTCSS; DTMF; tone squelch; carrier squelch; phonetics; operational problem resolution; Q signals

Question.text: What is the most common use of the “reverse split” function of a VHF/UHF transceiver?

Answer.text: Reduce power output
Increase power output
Listen on a repeater’s input frequency
Listen on a repeater’s output frequency

Question.text: What term describes the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted along with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?

Answer.text: Carrier squelch
Tone burst

Question.text: If a station is not strong enough to keep a repeater’s receiver squelch open, which of the following might allow you to receive the station’s signal?

Answer.text: Open the squelch on your radio
Listen on the repeater input frequency
Listen on the repeater output frequency
Increase your transmit power

Question.text: Which of the following could be the reason you are unable to access a repeater whose output you can hear?

Answer.text: Improper transceiver offset
The repeater may require a proper CTCSS tone from your transceiver
The repeater may require a proper DCS tone from your transceiver
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What might be the problem if a repeater user says your transmissions are breaking up on voice peaks?

Answer.text: You have the incorrect offset
You need to talk louder
You are talking too loudly
Your transmit power is too high

Question.text: What type of tones are used to control repeaters linked by the Internet Relay Linking Project (IRLP) protocol?
How can you join a digital repeater’s “talk group”?

Answer.text: Register your radio with the local FCC office
Join the repeater owner’s club
Program your radio with the group’s ID or code
Sign your call after the courtesy tone

Question.text: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?

Answer.text: Common courtesy should prevail, but no one has absolute right to an amateur frequency
Whoever has the strongest signal has priority on the frequency
Whoever has been on the frequency the longest has priority on the frequency
The station that has the weakest signal has priority on the frequency

Question.text: What is a “talk group” on a DMR digital repeater?

Answer.text: A group of operators sharing common interests
A way for groups of users to share a channel at different times without being heard by other users on the channel
A protocol that increases the signal-to-noise ratio when multiple repeaters are linked together
A net that meets at a particular time

Question.text: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?
Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?
Why are simplex channels designated in the VHF/UHF band plans?

Answer.text: So that stations within mutual communications range can communicate without tying up a repeater
For contest operation
For working DX only
So that stations with simple transmitters can access the repeater without automated offset

Question.text: Where may SSB phone be used in amateur bands above 50 MHz?

Answer.text: Only in sub-bands allocated to General class or higher licensees
Only on repeaters
In at least some portion of all these bands
On any band as long as power is limited to 25 watts

Question.text: Which of the following describes a linked repeater network?

Answer.text: A network of repeaters where signals received by one repeater are repeated by all the repeaters
A repeater with more than one receiver
Multiple repeaters with the same owner
A system of repeaters linked by APRS

Group.title: Public service: emergency and non-emergency operations; applicability of FCC rules; RACES and ARES; net and traffic procedures; operating restrictions during emergencies

Question.text: When do the FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?

Answer.text: When operating a RACES station
When operating under special FEMA rules
When operating under special ARES rules
Never, FCC rules always apply

Question.text: What is meant by the term "NCS" used in net operation?

Answer.text: Nominal Control System
Net Control Station
National Communications Standard
Normal Communications Syntax

Question.text: What should be done when using voice modes to ensure that voice messages containing unusual words are received correctly?

Answer.text: Send the words by voice and Morse code
Speak very loudly into the microphone
Spell the words using a standard phonetic alphabet
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What do RACES and ARES have in common?

Answer.text: They represent the two largest ham clubs in the United States
Both organizations broadcast road and weather information
Neither may handle emergency traffic supporting public service agencies
Both organizations may provide communications during emergencies

Question.text: What does the term “traffic” refer to in net operation?

Answer.text: Formal messages exchanged by net stations
The number of stations checking in and out of a net
Operation by mobile or portable stations
Requests to activate the net by a served agency

Question.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice to get the immediate attention of a net control station when reporting an emergency?

Answer.text: Repeat "SOS" three times followed by the call sign of the reporting station
Press the push-to-talk button three times
Begin your transmission by saying "Priority" or "Emergency" followed by your call sign
Play a pre-recorded emergency alert tone followed by your call sign

Question.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice for an amateur operator who has checked into a net?

Answer.text: Provided that the frequency is quiet, announce the station call sign and location every 5 minutes
Move 5 kHz away from the net's frequency and use high power to ask other hams to keep clear of the net frequency
Remain on frequency without transmitting until asked to do so by the net control station
All of the choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of good traffic handling?

Answer.text: Passing messages exactly as received
Making decisions as to whether messages are worthy of relay or delivery
Ensuring that any newsworthy messages are relayed to the news media
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Are amateur station control operators ever permitted to operate outside the frequency privileges of their license class?

Answer.text: Yes, but only when part of a FEMA emergency plan
Yes, but only when part of a RACES emergency plan
Yes, but only if necessary in situations involving the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

Question.text: What information is contained in the preamble of a formal traffic message?

Answer.text: The email address of the originating station
The address of the intended recipient
The telephone number of the addressee
The information needed to track the message

Question.text: What is meant by the term “check,” in reference to a formal traffic message?

Answer.text: The number of words or word equivalents in the text portion of the message
The value of a money order attached to the message
A list of stations that have relayed the message
A box on the message form that indicates that the message was received and/or relayed

Question.text: What is the Amateur Radio Emergency Service (ARES)?

Answer.text: Licensed amateurs who have voluntarily registered their qualifications and equipment for communications duty in the public service
Licensed amateurs who are members of the military and who voluntarily agreed to provide message handling services in the case of an emergency
A training program that provides licensing courses for those interested in obtaining an amateur license to use during emergencies
A training program that certifies amateur operators for membership in the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service

Subelement.title: Radio wave characteristics: properties of radio waves; propagation modes

Group.title: Radio wave characteristics: how a radio signal travels; fading; multipath; polarization; wavelength vs absorption; antenna orientation

Question.text: What should you do if another operator reports that your station’s 2 meter signals were strong just a moment ago, but now they are weak or distorted?

Answer.text: Change the batteries in your radio to a different type
Turn on the CTCSS tone
Ask the other operator to adjust his squelch control
Try moving a few feet or changing the direction of your antenna if possible, as reflections may be causing multi-path distortion

Question.text: Why might the range of VHF and UHF signals be greater in the winter?

Answer.text: Less ionospheric absorption
Less absorption by vegetation
Less solar activity
Less tropospheric absorption

Question.text: What antenna polarization is normally used for long-distance weak-signal CW and SSB contacts using the VHF and UHF bands?

Answer.text: Right-hand circular
Left-hand circular

Question.text: What can happen if the antennas at opposite ends of a VHF or UHF line of sight radio link are not using the same polarization?

Answer.text: The modulation sidebands might become inverted
Signals could be significantly weaker
Signals have an echo effect on voices
Nothing significant will happen

Question.text: When using a directional antenna, how might your station be able to access a distant repeater if buildings or obstructions are blocking the direct line of sight path?

Answer.text: Change from vertical to horizontal polarization
Try to find a path that reflects signals to the repeater
Try the long path
Increase the antenna SWR

Question.text: What term is commonly used to describe the rapid fluttering sound sometimes heard from mobile stations that are moving while transmitting?

Answer.text: Picket fencing
Frequency shifting

Question.text: What type of wave carries radio signals between transmitting and receiving stations?

Answer.text: Surface acoustic

Question.text: Which of the following is a likely cause of irregular fading of signals received by ionospheric reflection?

Answer.text: Frequency shift due to Faraday rotation

Answer.text: Between the antenna and receiver
At the output of the transmitter's power amplifier
Between a transmitter and antenna tuner
At the receiver's audio output

Group.title: Common transmitter and receiver problems: symptoms of overload and overdrive; distortion; causes of interference; interference and consumer electronics; part 15 devices; over-modulation; RF feedback; off frequency signals

Question.text: What can you do if you are told your FM handheld or mobile transceiver is over-deviating?

Answer.text: Talk louder into the microphone
Let the transceiver cool off
Change to a higher power level
Talk farther away from the microphone

Question.text: What would cause a broadcast AM or FM radio to receive an amateur radio transmission unintentionally?

Answer.text: The receiver is unable to reject strong signals outside the AM or FM band
The microphone gain of the transmitter is turned up too high
The audio amplifier of the transmitter is overloaded
The deviation of an FM transmitter is set too low

Question.text: Which of the following can cause radio frequency interference?

Answer.text: Fundamental overload
Spurious emissions
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a way to reduce or eliminate interference from an amateur transmitter to a nearby telephone?

Answer.text: Put a filter on the amateur transmitter
Reduce the microphone gain
Reduce the SWR on the transmitter transmission line
Put an RF filter on the telephone

Question.text: How can overload of a non-amateur radio or TV receiver by an amateur signal be reduced or eliminated?

Answer.text: Block the amateur signal with a filter at the antenna input of the affected receiver
Block the interfering signal with a filter on the amateur transmitter
Switch the transmitter from FM to SSB
Switch the transmitter to a narrow-band mode

Question.text: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?

Answer.text: Make sure that your station is functioning properly and that it does not cause interference to your own radio or television when it is tuned to the same channel
Immediately turn off your transmitter and contact the nearest FCC office for assistance
Tell them that your license gives you the right to transmit and nothing can be done to reduce the interference
Install a harmonic doubler on the output of your transmitter and tune it until the interference is eliminated

Question.text: Which of the following can reduce overload to a VHF transceiver from a nearby FM broadcast station?

Answer.text: RF preamplifier
Double-shielded coaxial cable
Using headphones instead of the speaker
Band-reject filter

Question.text: What should you do if something in a neighbor’s home is causing harmful interference to your amateur station?

Answer.text: Work with your neighbor to identify the offending device
Politely inform your neighbor about the rules that prohibit the use of devices that cause interference
Check your station and make sure it meets the standards of good amateur practice
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is a Part 15 device?

Answer.text: An unlicensed device that may emit low-powered radio signals on frequencies used by a licensed service
An amplifier that has been type-certified for amateur radio
A device for long-distance communications using special codes sanctioned by the International Amateur Radio Union
A type of test set used to determine whether a transmitter complies with FCC regulation 91.15

Question.text: What might be a problem if you receive a report that your audio signal through the repeater is distorted or unintelligible?

Answer.text: Your transmitter is slightly off frequency
Your batteries are running low
You are in a bad location
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is a symptom of RF feedback in a transmitter or transceiver?

Answer.text: Excessive SWR at the antenna connection
The transmitter will not stay on the desired frequency
Reports of garbled, distorted, or unintelligible voice transmissions
Frequent blowing of power supply fuses

Question.text: What should be the first step to resolve cable TV interference from your ham radio transmission?

Answer.text: Add a low-pass filter to the TV antenna input
Add a high-pass filter to the TV antenna input
Add a preamplifier to the TV antenna input
Be sure all TV coaxial connectors are installed properly

Group.title: Antenna measurements and troubleshooting: measuring SWR; dummy loads; coaxial cables; causes of feed line failures

Question.text: What is the primary purpose of a dummy load?

Answer.text: To prevent transmitting signals over the air when making tests
To prevent over-modulation of a transmitter
To improve the efficiency of an antenna
To improve the signal-to-noise ratio of a receiver

Question.text: Which of the following instruments can be used to determine if an antenna is resonant at the desired operating frequency?

Answer.text: A VTVM
An antenna analyzer
A Q meter
A frequency counter

Question.text: What, in general terms, is standing wave ratio (SWR)?

Answer.text: A measure of how well a load is matched to a transmission line
The ratio of high to low impedance in a feed line
The transmitter efficiency ratio
An indication of the quality of your station’s ground connection

Question.text: What reading on an SWR meter indicates a perfect impedance match between the antenna and the feed line?

Answer.text: 2 to 1
1 to 3
1 to 1
10 to 1

Question.text: Why do most solid-state amateur radio transmitters reduce output power as SWR increases?

Answer.text: To protect the output amplifier transistors
To comply with FCC rules on spectral purity
Because power supplies cannot supply enough current at high SWR
To improve the impedance match to the feed line

Question.text: What does an SWR reading of 4:1 indicate?

Answer.text: Loss of -4 dB
Good impedance match
Gain of +4 dB
Impedance mismatch

Question.text: What happens to power lost in a feed line?

Answer.text: It increases the SWR
It comes back into your transmitter and could cause damage
It is converted into heat
It can cause distortion of your signal

Question.text: What instrument other than an SWR meter could you use to determine if a feed line and antenna are properly matched?

Answer.text: Iambic pentameter
Directional wattmeter

Question.text: Which of the following is the most common cause for failure of coaxial cables?

Answer.text: Moisture contamination
Gamma rays
The velocity factor exceeds 1.0

Question.text: Why should the outer jacket of coaxial cable be resistant to ultraviolet light?

Answer.text: Ultraviolet resistant jackets prevent harmonic radiation
Ultraviolet light can increase losses in the cable’s jacket
Ultraviolet and RF signals can mix, causing interference
Ultraviolet light can damage the jacket and allow water to enter the cable

Question.text: What is a disadvantage of air core coaxial cable when compared to foam or solid dielectric types?

Answer.text: It has more loss per foot
It cannot be used for VHF or UHF antennas
It requires special techniques to prevent water absorption
It cannot be used at below freezing temperatures

Question.text: What does a dummy load consist of?

Answer.text: A high-gain amplifier and a TR switch
A non-inductive resistor and a heat sink
A low-voltage power supply and a DC relay
A 50 ohm reactance used to terminate a transmission line

Group.title: Basic repair and testing: soldering; using basic test instruments; connecting a voltmeter, ammeter, or ohmmeter

Question.text: Which instrument would you use to measure electric potential or electromotive force?

Answer.text: An ammeter
A voltmeter
A wavemeter
An ohmmeter

Question.text: What is the correct way to connect a voltmeter to a circuit?

Answer.text: In series with the circuit
In parallel with the circuit
In quadrature with the circuit
In phase with the circuit

Question.text: How is a simple ammeter connected to a circuit?

Answer.text: In series with the circuit
In parallel with the circuit
In quadrature with the circuit
In phase with the circuit

Question.text: Which instrument is used to measure electric current?

Answer.text: An ohmmeter
A wavemeter
A voltmeter
An ammeter

Question.text: What instrument is used to measure resistance?

Answer.text: An oscilloscope
A spectrum analyzer
A noise bridge
An ohmmeter

Question.text: Which of the following might damage a multimeter?

Answer.text: Measuring a voltage too small for the chosen scale
Leaving the meter in the milliamps position overnight
Attempting to measure voltage when using the resistance setting
Not allowing it to warm up properly

Question.text: Which of the following measurements are commonly made using a multimeter?

Answer.text: SWR and RF power
Signal strength and noise
Impedance and reactance
Voltage and resistance

Question.text: Which of the following types of solder is best for radio and electronic use?

Answer.text: Acid-core solder
Silver solder
Rosin-core solder
Aluminum solder

Question.text: What is the characteristic appearance of a cold solder joint?

Answer.text: Dark black spots
A bright or shiny surface
A grainy or dull surface
A greenish tint

Question.text: What is probably happening when an ohmmeter, connected across an unpowered circuit, initially indicates a low resistance and then shows increasing resistance with time?

Answer.text: The ohmmeter is defective
The circuit contains a large capacitor
The circuit contains a large inductor
The circuit is a relaxation oscillator

Question.text: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring circuit resistance with an ohmmeter?

Answer.text: Ensure that the applied voltages are correct
Ensure that the circuit is not powered
Ensure that the circuit is grounded
Ensure that the circuit is operating at the correct frequency

Question.text: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring high voltages with a voltmeter?

Answer.text: Ensure that the voltmeter has very low impedance
Ensure that the voltmeter and leads are rated for use at the voltages to be measured
Ensure that the circuit is grounded through the voltmeter
Ensure that the voltmeter is set to the correct frequency

Subelement.title: Modulation modes: amateur satellite operation; operating activities; non-voice and digital communications

Group.title: Modulation modes: bandwidth of various signals; choice of emission type

Question.text: Which of the following is a form of amplitude modulation?

Answer.text: Spread spectrum
Packet radio
Single sideband
Phase shift keying (PSK)

Question.text: What type of modulation is most commonly used for VHF packet radio transmissions?
Which type of voice mode is most often used for long-distance (weak signal) contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
Which type of modulation is most commonly used for VHF and UHF voice repeaters?
Which of the following types of emission has the narrowest bandwidth?

Answer.text: FM voice
SSB voice
Slow-scan TV

Question.text: Which sideband is normally used for 10 meter HF, VHF, and UHF single-sideband communications?

Answer.text: Upper sideband
Lower sideband
Suppressed sideband
Inverted sideband

Question.text: What is an advantage of single sideband (SSB) over FM for voice transmissions?

Answer.text: SSB signals are easier to tune
SSB signals are less susceptible to interference
SSB signals have narrower bandwidth
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the approximate bandwidth of a single sideband (SSB) voice signal?

Answer.text: 1 kHz
3 kHz
6 kHz
15 kHz

Question.text: What is the approximate bandwidth of a VHF repeater FM phone signal?

Answer.text: Less than 500 Hz
About 150 kHz
Between 10 and 15 kHz
Between 50 and 125 kHz

Question.text: What is the typical bandwidth of analog fast-scan TV transmissions on the 70 centimeter band?

Answer.text: More than 10 MHz
About 6 MHz
About 3 MHz
About 1 MHz

Question.text: What is the approximate maximum bandwidth required to transmit a CW signal?

Answer.text: 2.4 kHz
150 Hz

Group.title: Amateur satellite operation; Doppler shift; basic orbits; operating protocols; transmitter power considerations; telemetry and telecommand; satellite tracking

Question.text: What telemetry information is typically transmitted by satellite beacons?

Answer.text: The signal strength of received signals
Time of day accurate to plus or minus 1/10 second
Health and status of the satellite
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the impact of using too much effective radiated power on a satellite uplink?

Answer.text: Possibility of commanding the satellite to an improper mode
Blocking access by other users
Overloading the satellite batteries
Possibility of rebooting the satellite control computer

Question.text: Which of the following are provided by satellite tracking programs?

Answer.text: Maps showing the real-time position of the satellite track over the earth
The time, azimuth, and elevation of the start, maximum altitude, and end of a pass
The apparent frequency of the satellite transmission, including effects of Doppler shift
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What mode of transmission is used for satellite beacons?

Answer.text: All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is a satellite beacon?

Answer.text: The primary transmit antenna on the satellite
An indicator light that shows where to point your antenna
A reflective surface on the satellite
A transmission from a satellite that contains status information

Question.text: Which of the following are inputs to a satellite tracking program?

Answer.text: The weight of the satellite
The Keplerian elements
The last observed time of zero Doppler shift
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: With regard to satellite communications, what is Doppler shift?

Answer.text: A change in the satellite orbit
A mode where the satellite receives signals on one band and transmits on another
An observed change in signal frequency caused by relative motion between the satellite and the earth station
A special digital communications mode for some satellites

Question.text: What is meant by the statement that a satellite is operating in mode U/V?

Answer.text: The satellite uplink is in the 15 meter band and the downlink is in the 10 meter band
The satellite uplink is in the 70 centimeter band and the downlink is in the 2 meter band
The satellite operates using ultraviolet frequencies
The satellite frequencies are usually variable

Question.text: What causes spin fading of satellite signals?

Answer.text: Circular polarized noise interference radiated from the sun
Rotation of the satellite and its antennas
Doppler shift of the received signal
Interfering signals within the satellite uplink band

Question.text: What do the initials LEO tell you about an amateur satellite?

Answer.text: The satellite battery is in Low Energy Operation mode
The satellite is performing a Lunar Ejection Orbit maneuver
The satellite is in a Low Earth Orbit
The satellite uses Light Emitting Optics

Question.text: Who may receive telemetry from a space station?

Answer.text: Anyone who can receive the telemetry signal
A licensed radio amateur with a transmitter equipped for interrogating the satellite
A licensed radio amateur who has been certified by the protocol developer
A licensed radio amateur who has registered for an access code from AMSAT

Question.text: Which of the following is a good way to judge whether your uplink power is neither too low nor too high?

Answer.text: Check your signal strength report in the telemetry data
Listen for distortion on your downlink signal
Your signal strength on the downlink should be about the same as the beacon
All of these choices are correct

Group.title: Operating activities: radio direction finding; radio control; contests; linking over the internet; grid locators

Question.text: Which of the following methods is used to locate sources of noise interference or jamming?

Answer.text: Doppler radar
Radio direction finding
Phase locking

Question.text: Which of these items would be useful for a hidden transmitter hunt?

Answer.text: Calibrated SWR meter
A directional antenna
A calibrated noise bridge
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What operating activity involves contacting as many stations as possible during a specified period?

Answer.text: Net operations
Public service events
Simulated emergency exercises

Question.text: Which of the following is good procedure when contacting another station in a radio contest?

Answer.text: Sign only the last two letters of your call if there are many other stations calling
Contact the station twice to be sure that you are in his log
Send only the minimum information needed for proper identification and the contest exchange
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is a grid locator?

Answer.text: A letter-number designator assigned to a geographic location
A letter-number designator assigned to an azimuth and elevation

Question.text: How is access to some IRLP nodes accomplished?

Answer.text: By obtaining a password that is sent via voice to the node
By using DTMF signals
By entering the proper internet password
By using CTCSS tone codes

Question.text: What is meant by Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP) as used in amateur radio?

Answer.text: A set of rules specifying how to identify your station when linked over the internet to another station
A set of guidelines for contacting DX stations during contests using internet access
A technique for measuring the modulation quality of a transmitter using remote sites monitored via the internet

Question.text: What is the Internet Radio Linking Project (IRLP)?

Answer.text: A technique to connect amateur radio systems, such as repeaters, via the internet using Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)

A system for informing amateurs in real time of the frequency of active DX stations

Question.text: How might you obtain a list of active nodes that use VoIP?

Answer.text: By subscribing to an on line service
From on line repeater lists maintained by the local repeater frequency coordinator
From a repeater directory
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What must be done before you may use the Echolink system to communicate using a repeater?

Answer.text: You must complete the required Echolink training
You must have purchased a license to use the Echolink software
You must be sponsored by a current Echolink user
You must register your call sign and provide proof of license

Question.text: What name is given to an amateur radio station that is used to connect other amateur stations to the internet?

Answer.text: A gateway
A repeater
A digipeater
A beacon

Group.title: Non-voice and digital communications: image signals; digital modes; CW; packet radio; PSK31; APRS; error detection and correction; NTSC; amateur radio networking; Digital Mobile/Migration Radio

Question.text: Which of the following is a digital communications mode?

Answer.text: Packet radio
IEEE 802.11
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What does the term “APRS” mean?

Answer.text: Automatic Packet Reporting System
Associated Public Radio Station
Auto Planning Radio Set-up
Advanced Polar Radio System

Question.text: Which of the following devices is used to provide data to the transmitter when sending automatic position reports from a mobile amateur radio station?

Answer.text: The vehicle speedometer
A WWV receiver
A connection to a broadcast FM sub-carrier receiver
A Global Positioning System receiver

Question.text: What type of transmission is indicated by the term "NTSC?"

Answer.text: A Normal Transmission mode in Static Circuit
A special mode for earth satellite uplink
An analog fast scan color TV signal

Question.text: Which of the following is an application of APRS (Automatic Packet Reporting System)?

Answer.text: Providing real-time tactical digital communications in conjunction with a map showing the locations of stations
Showing automatically the number of packets transmitted via PACTOR during a specific time interval
Providing voice over internet connection between repeaters

Question.text: What does the abbreviation "PSK" mean?

Answer.text: Pulse Shift Keying
Phase Shift Keying
Packet Short Keying
Phased Slide Keying

Question.text: Which of the following best describes DMR (Digital Mobile Radio or Digital Migration Radio)?

Answer.text: A technique for time-multiplexing two digital voice signals on a single 12.5 kHz repeater channel
An automatic position tracking mode for FM mobiles communicating through repeaters
An automatic computer logging technique for hands-off logging when communicating while operating a vehicle

Question.text: Which of the following may be included in packet transmissions?

Answer.text: A check sum that permits error detection
A header that contains the call sign of the station to which the information is being sent
Automatic repeat request in case of error
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What code is used when sending CW in the amateur bands?

Answer.text: International Morse
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following operating activities is supported by digital mode software in the WSJT suite?

Answer.text: Moonbounce or Earth-Moon-Earth
Weak-signal propagation beacons
Meteor scatter
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is an ARQ transmission system?

Answer.text: A special transmission format limited to video signals
A system used to encrypt command signals to an amateur radio satellite
A digital scheme whereby the receiving station detects errors and sends a request to the sending station to retransmit the information
A method of compressing the data in a message so more information can be sent in a shorter time

Question.text: Which of the following best describes Broadband-Hamnet(TM), also referred to as a high-speed multi-media network?

Answer.text: An amateur-radio-based data network using commercial Wi-Fi gear with modified firmware
A wide-bandwidth digital voice mode employing DRM protocols
A satellite communications network using modified commercial satellite TV hardware
An internet linking protocol used to network repeaters

Question.text: What is FT8?

Answer.text: A wideband FM voice mode
A digital mode capable of operating in low signal-to-noise conditions that transmits on 15-second intervals
An eight channel multiplex mode for FM repeaters
A digital slow scan TV mode with forward error correction and automatic color compensation

Question.text: What is an electronic keyer?

Answer.text: A device for switching antennas from transmit to receive
A device for voice activated switching from receive to transmit
A device that assists in manual sending of Morse code
An interlock to prevent unauthorized use of a radio

Group.title: Antennas: vertical and horizontal polarization; concept of gain; common portable and mobile antennas; relationships between resonant length and frequency; concept of dipole antennas

Question.text: What is a beam antenna?

Answer.text: An antenna built from aluminum I-beams
An omnidirectional antenna invented by Clarence Beam
An antenna that concentrates signals in one direction
An antenna that reverses the phase of received signals

Question.text: Which of the following describes a type of antenna loading?

Answer.text: Inserting an inductor in the radiating portion of the antenna to make it electrically longer
Inserting a resistor in the radiating portion of the antenna to make it resonant
Installing a spring in the base of a mobile vertical antenna to make it more flexible
Strengthening the radiating elements of a beam antenna to better resist wind damage

Question.text: Which of the following describes a simple dipole oriented parallel to the Earth's surface?

Answer.text: A ground-wave antenna
A horizontally polarized antenna
A rhombic antenna
A vertically polarized antenna

Question.text: What is a disadvantage of the “rubber duck” antenna supplied with most handheld radio transceivers when compared to a full-sized quarter-wave antenna?

Answer.text: It does not transmit or receive as effectively

All of these choices are correct

Question.text: How would you change a dipole antenna to make it resonant on a higher frequency?

Answer.text: Lengthen it
Insert coils in series with radiating wires
Shorten it
Add capacitive loading to the ends of the radiating wires

Question.text: What type of antennas are the quad, Yagi, and dish?

Answer.text: Non-resonant antennas
Log periodic antennas
Directional antennas
Isotropic antennas

Question.text: What is a disadvantage of using a handheld VHF transceiver, with its integral antenna, inside a vehicle?

Answer.text: Signals might not propagate well due to the shielding effect of the vehicle
It might cause the transceiver to overheat

All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the approximate length, in inches, of a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for 146 MHz?
What is the approximate length, in inches, of a half-wavelength 6 meter dipole antenna?
In which direction does a half-wave dipole antenna radiate the strongest signal?

Answer.text: Equally in all directions
Off the ends of the antenna
Broadside to the antenna
In the direction of the feed line

Question.text: What is the gain of an antenna?

Answer.text: The additional power that is added to the transmitter power
The additional power that is lost in the antenna when transmitting on a higher frequency
The increase in signal strength in a specified direction compared to a reference antenna
The increase in impedance on receive or transmit compared to a reference antenna

Question.text: What is an advantage of using a properly mounted 5/8 wavelength antenna for VHF or UHF mobile service?

Answer.text: It has a lower radiation angle and more gain than a 1/4 wavelength antenna
It has very high angle radiation for better communicating through a repeater
It eliminates distortion caused by reflected signals
It has 10 times the power gain of a 1/4 wavelength design

Group.title: Feed lines: types, attenuation vs frequency, selecting; SWR concepts; Antenna tuners (couplers); RF Connectors: selecting, weather protection

Question.text: Why is it important to have low SWR when using coaxial cable feed line?

Answer.text: To reduce television interference
To reduce signal loss
To prolong antenna life
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the impedance of most coaxial cables used in amateur radio installations?

Answer.text: 8 ohms
50 ohms
600 ohms
12 ohms

Question.text: Why is coaxial cable the most common feed line selected for amateur radio antenna systems?

Answer.text: It is easy to use and requires few special installation considerations
It has less loss than any other type of feed line
It can handle more power than any other type of feed line
It is less expensive than any other type of feed line

Question.text: What is the major function of an antenna tuner (antenna coupler)?

Answer.text: It matches the antenna system impedance to the transceiver's output impedance
It helps a receiver automatically tune in weak stations
It allows an antenna to be used on both transmit and receive
It automatically selects the proper antenna for the frequency band being used

Question.text: In general, what happens as the frequency of a signal passing through coaxial cable is increased?

Answer.text: The characteristic impedance decreases
The loss decreases
The characteristic impedance increases
The loss increases

Question.text: Which of the following connectors is most suitable for frequencies above 400 MHz?

Answer.text: A UHF (PL-259/SO-239) connector
A Type N connector
An RS-213 connector
A DB-25 connector

Question.text: Which of the following is true of PL-259 type coax connectors?

Answer.text: They are preferred for microwave operation
They are watertight
They are commonly used at HF frequencies
They are a bayonet type connector

Question.text: Why should coax connectors exposed to the weather be sealed against water intrusion?

Answer.text: To prevent an increase in feed line loss
To prevent interference to telephones
To keep the jacket from becoming loose
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What can cause erratic changes in SWR readings?

Answer.text: The transmitter is being modulated
A loose connection in an antenna or a feed line
The transmitter is being over-modulated
Interference from other stations is distorting your signal

Question.text: What is the electrical difference between RG-58 and RG-8 coaxial cable?

Answer.text: There is no significant difference between the two types
RG-58 cable has two shields
RG-8 cable has less loss at a given frequency
RG-58 cable can handle higher power levels

Question.text: Which of the following types of feed line has the lowest loss at VHF and UHF?

Answer.text: 50-ohm flexible coax
Multi-conductor unbalanced cable
Air-insulated hard line
75-ohm flexible coax

Subelement.title: Electrical safety: AC and DC power circuits; antenna installation; RF hazards

Group.title: Power circuits and hazards: hazardous voltages; fuses and circuit breakers; grounding; lightning protection; battery safety; electrical code compliance

Question.text: Which of the following is a safety hazard of a 12-volt storage battery?

Answer.text: Touching both terminals with the hands can cause electrical shock
Shorting the terminals can cause burns, fire, or an explosion
RF emissions from the battery
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What health hazard is presented by electrical current flowing through the body?

Answer.text: It may cause injury by heating tissue
It may disrupt the electrical functions of cells
It may cause involuntary muscle contractions
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: In the United States, what is connected to the green wire in a three-wire electrical AC plug?

Answer.text: Equipment ground
The white wire

Question.text: What is the purpose of a fuse in an electrical circuit?

Answer.text: To prevent power supply ripple from damaging a circuit
To interrupt power in case of overload
To limit current to prevent shocks
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Why is it unwise to install a 20-ampere fuse in the place of a 5-ampere fuse?

Answer.text: The larger fuse would be likely to blow because it is rated for higher current
The power supply ripple would greatly increase
Excessive current could cause a fire
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is a good way to guard against electrical shock at your station?

Answer.text: Use three-wire cords and plugs for all AC powered equipment
Connect all AC powered station equipment to a common safety ground
Use a circuit protected by a ground-fault interrupter
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of these precautions should be taken when installing devices for lightning protection in a coaxial cable feed line?

Answer.text: Include a parallel bypass switch for each protector so that it can be switched out of the circuit when running high power
Include a series switch in the ground line of each protector to prevent RF overload from inadvertently damaging the protector
Keep the ground wires from each protector separate and connected to station ground
Mount all of the protectors on a metal plate that is in turn connected to an external ground rod

Question.text: What safety equipment should always be included in home-built equipment that is powered from 120V AC power circuits?

Answer.text: A fuse or circuit breaker in series with the AC hot conductor
An AC voltmeter across the incoming power source
An inductor in parallel with the AC power source
A capacitor in series with the AC power source

Question.text: What should be done to all external ground rods or earth connections?

Answer.text: Waterproof them with silicone caulk or electrical tape
Keep them as far apart as possible
Bond them together with heavy wire or conductive strap
Tune them for resonance on the lowest frequency of operation

Question.text: What can happen if a lead-acid storage battery is charged or discharged too quickly?

Answer.text: The battery could overheat, give off flammable gas, or explode
The voltage can become reversed
The memory effect will reduce the capacity of the battery
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What kind of hazard might exist in a power supply when it is turned off and disconnected?

Answer.text: Static electricity could damage the grounding system
Circulating currents inside the transformer might cause damage
The fuse might blow if you remove the cover
You might receive an electric shock from the charge stored in large capacitors

Group.title: Antenna safety: tower safety and grounding; erecting an antenna support; safely installing an antenna

Question.text: When should members of a tower work team wear a hard hat and safety glasses?

Answer.text: At all times except when climbing the tower
At all times except when belted firmly to the tower
At all times when any work is being done on the tower
Only when the tower exceeds 30 feet in height

Question.text: What is a good precaution to observe before climbing an antenna tower?

Answer.text: Make sure that you wear a grounded wrist strap
Remove all tower grounding connections
Put on a carefully inspected climbing harness (fall arrester) and safety glasses
All of the these choices are correct

Question.text: Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?

Answer.text: When no electrical work is being performed
When no mechanical work is being performed
When the work being done is not more than 20 feet above the ground

Question.text: Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?

Answer.text: Wear a ground strap connected to your wrist at all times
Insulate the base of the tower to avoid lightning strikes
Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the purpose of a gin pole?

Answer.text: To temporarily replace guy wires
To be used in place of a safety harness
To lift tower sections or antennas
To provide a temporary ground

Question.text: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?

Answer.text: Half the width of your property
The height of the power line above ground
1/2 wavelength at the operating frequency
Enough so that if the antenna falls unexpectedly, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

Question.text: Which of the following is an important safety rule to remember when using a crank-up tower?

Answer.text: This type of tower must never be painted
This type of tower must never be grounded
This type of tower must not be climbed unless retracted or mechanical safety locking devices have been installed
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is considered to be a proper grounding method for a tower?

Answer.text: A single four-foot ground rod, driven into the ground no more than 12 inches from the base
A ferrite-core RF choke connected between the tower and ground
Separate eight-foot long ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other
A connection between the tower base and a cold water pipe

Question.text: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?

Answer.text: The antenna will not work properly because of induced voltages
The utility company will charge you an extra monthly fee
The antenna could contact high-voltage power lines
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is true when installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection?

Answer.text: Only non-insulated wire must be used
Wires must be carefully routed with precise right-angle bends
Sharp bends must be avoided
Common grounds must be avoided

Question.text: Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?

Answer.text: FCC Part 97 Rules
Local electrical codes
FAA tower lighting regulations
UL recommended practices

Question.text: Which of the following is good practice when installing ground wires on a tower for lightning protection?

Answer.text: Put a loop in the ground connection to prevent water damage to the ground system
Make sure that all bends in the ground wires are clean, right-angle bends
Ensure that connections are short and direct
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines?

Answer.text: Secure the guy if the turnbuckle breaks
Prevent loosening of the guy line from vibration
Prevent theft or vandalism
Deter unauthorized climbing of the tower

Group.title: RF hazards: radiation exposure; proximity to antennas; recognized safe power levels; exposure to others; radiation types; duty cycle

Question.text: What type of radiation are VHF and UHF radio signals?

Answer.text: Gamma radiation
Ionizing radiation
Alpha radiation
Non-ionizing radiation

Question.text: Which of the following frequencies has the lowest value for Maximum Permissible Exposure limit?

Answer.text: 3.5 MHz
50 MHz
440 MHz
1296 MHz

Question.text: What is the maximum power level that an amateur radio station may use at VHF frequencies before an RF exposure evaluation is required?

Answer.text: 1500 watts PEP transmitter output
1 watt forward power
50 watts PEP at the antenna
50 watts PEP reflected power

Question.text: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?

Answer.text: Frequency and power level of the RF field
Distance from the antenna to a person
Radiation pattern of the antenna
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?

Answer.text: Lower frequency RF fields have more energy than higher frequency fields
Lower frequency RF fields do not penetrate the human body
Higher frequency RF fields are transient in nature
The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

Question.text: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine that your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?

Answer.text: By calculation based on FCC OET Bulletin 65
By calculation based on computer modeling
By measurement of field strength using calibrated equipment
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What could happen if a person accidentally touched your antenna while you were transmitting?

Answer.text: Touching the antenna could cause television interference
They might receive a painful RF burn
They might develop radiation poisoning
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following actions might amateur operators take to prevent exposure to RF radiation in excess of FCC-supplied limits?

Answer.text: Relocate antennas
Relocate the transmitter
Increase the duty cycle
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?

Answer.text: By informing the FCC of any changes made in your station
By re-evaluating the station whenever an item of equipment is changed
By making sure your antennas have low SWR
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?

Answer.text: It affects the average exposure of people to radiation
It affects the peak exposure of people to radiation
It takes into account the antenna feed line loss
It takes into account the thermal effects of the final amplifier

Question.text: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?

Answer.text: The difference between the lowest power output and the highest power output of a transmitter
The difference between the PEP and average power output of a transmitter
The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting
The percentage of time that a transmitter is not transmitting

Question.text: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?

Answer.text: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause genetic damage
RF radiation can only be detected with an RF dosimeter
RF radiation is limited in range to a few feet
RF radiation is perfectly safe

Question.text: If the averaging time for exposure is 6 minutes, how much power density is permitted if the signal is present for 3 minutes and absent for 3 minutes rather than being present for the entire 6 minutes?

Answer.text: 3 times as much
1/2 as much
2 times as much
There is no adjustment allowed for shorter exposure times
